articles.headline: Hunting Leaks, Trump Officials Focused on Democrats in Congress
articles.snippet: The Justice Department seized records from Apple for metadata of House Intelligence Committee members, their aides and family members.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department seized records from Apple for metadata of House Intelligence Committee members, their aides and family members.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Justice Department investigated who was behind leaks of classified information early in the Trump administration, it took a highly unusual step: Prosecutors subpoenaed Apple for data from the accounts of at least two Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee, aides and family members. One was a minor.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Nicholas Fandos, Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: America May Be ‘Back’ in Europe, but How Much Has Really Changed?
articles.snippet: Despite the feel-good imagery expected to be on display at the Group of 7 meeting, many Europeans suspect that President Biden is little more interested in give-and-take than was his predecessor.
articles.abstract: Despite the feel-good imagery expected to be on display at the Group of 7 meeting, many Europeans suspect that President Biden is little more interested in give-and-take than was his predecessor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALMOUTH, England — Few images captured the rupture in trans-Atlantic relations better than that of President Donald J. Trump in 2018, arms folded across his chest as he resisted Chancellor Angela Merkel and other frustrated leaders in their doomed effort to salvage their summit meeting in Canada.

articles.headline: China Still Buys American DNA Equipment for Xinjiang Despite Blocks
articles.snippet: The U.S. government has long tried to prevent the sales over concerns about rights abuses and surveillance. Documents show those efforts have failed.
articles.abstract: The U.S. government has long tried to prevent the sales over concerns about rights abuses and surveillance. Documents show those efforts have failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The police in the Chinese region of Xinjiang are still buying hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of American DNA equipment despite warnings from the U.S. government that the sale of such technologies could be used to enable human rights abuses in the region.

articles.headline: Meager Rewards for Workers, Exceptionally Rich Pay for C.E.O.s
articles.snippet: The gap between workers and C.E.O.s widened during the pandemic as public companies granted top executives some of the richest pay packages ever.
articles.abstract: The gap between workers and C.E.O.s widened during the pandemic as public companies granted top executives some of the richest pay packages ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even in a gilded age for executive pay, 2020 was a blowout year.

articles.headline: British Restaurants Are Battling a Staff Crisis, Worsened by Brexit
articles.snippet: A shortage of workers is forcing restaurants to turn away eager customers and confront a bigger problem: how to make hospitality an industry where people want to work.
articles.abstract: A shortage of workers is forcing restaurants to turn away eager customers and confront a bigger problem: how to make hospitality an industry where people want to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the wealthy central London enclave of Belgravia, where a two-bedroom apartment is advertised for 1.7 million pounds, or $2.4 million, and Maseratis and Bentleys line the streets, the battle for restaurant staff has become downright underhanded.

articles.headline: Europe’s Summer of Recovery Is More Fragile Than It Looks
articles.snippet: An anticipated surge of tourism in Portugal is suddenly not at all certain — a symbol of the global economy’s continued struggle with pandemic uncertainty.
articles.abstract: An anticipated surge of tourism in Portugal is suddenly not at all certain — a symbol of the global economy’s continued struggle with pandemic uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUFEIRA, Portugal — Until last week, Raissa Moura and her co-workers at the reception desk of the Pine Cliffs Resort were feeling optimistic that life was returning to normal along Portugal’s southern coast.
